actions-list.actionItem: Pursuant to the provisions of H. Res. 241, the Committee of the Whole proceeded with 10 minutes of debate on the Boebert amendment No. 4.

An amendment, offered by Mrs. Boebert,  numbered 4 printed in House Report 118-12 to amend Section 104 to include Parent's Right to Know if their child's school allows a person whose biological sex is male to use restrooms or changing rooms desginated for women or girls.
On agreeing to the Boebert amendment; Agreed to by voice vote.
Pursuant to the provisions of H. Res. 241, the Committee of the Whole proceeded with 10 minutes of debate on the Boebert amendment No. 3.

An amendment, offered by Mrs. Boebert,  numbered 3 printed in House Report 118-12 to amend Section 104 to include Parent's Right to Know if their child's school operates, sponsors, or facilitates athletic programs or activities to permit a person whose biological sex is male to participate in an athletic program or activity that is designated for women and girls.
On agreeing to the Foxx amendment; Agreed to by voice vote.
Pursuant to the provisions of H. Res. 241, the Committee of the Whole proceeded with 10 minutes of debate on the Foxx amendment No. 2.

An amendment, offered by Ms. Foxx,  numbered 2 printed in House Report 118-12 to align the list of rights school districts must provide notice of to actions school districts must take; amends a sense of Congress to express support for parents fundamental rights to direct the education of their children and that courts should use the strict scrutiny test to evaluate laws involving those rights.
On agreeing to the Bacon amendment; Agreed to by voice vote.
Pursuant to the provisions of H. Res. 241, the Committee of the Whole proceeded with 10 minutes of debate on the Bacon amendment No. 1.

An amendment, offered by Mr. Bacon,  numbered 1 printed in House Report 118-12 to require Local Education Agencies (LEA) to provide the parents of a child who is a student in an elementary school or secondary school the number of school counselors in that school.
The Committee of the Whole proceeded with two hours of general debate on H.R. 5.
The Speaker designated the Honorable Mike Flood to act as Chairman of the Committee.
House resolved itself into the Committee of the Whole House on the state of the Union pursuant to H. Res. 241 and Rule XVIII.
Rule provides for consideration of H.R. 5 with 2 hours of general debate. Motion to recommit allowed. Measure will be considered read. Specified amendments are in order.
Considered under the provisions of rule H. Res. 241. H.R. 5 — "To ensure the rights of parents are honored and protected in the Nation's public schools."
Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.

actions-list.header: On motion to suspend the rules and pass the bill Agreed to by the Yeas and Nays: (2/3 required): 388
actions-list.actionItem: 33 (Roll no. 148).

Considered as unfinished business. H.R. 406 — "To provide for the treatment of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations as an international organization for purposes of the International Organizations Immunities Act, and for other purposes."
Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.

actions-list.header: On agreeing to the resolution Agreed to by recorded vote: 218
On ordering the previous question Agreed to by the Yeas and Nays: 219

actions-list.actionItem: Considered as unfinished business. H. Res. 241 — "Providing for consideration of the bill (H.R. 5) to ensure the rights of parents are honored and protected in the Nation's public schools."

The Chair announced that the unfinished business was on the question of ordering the previous question on H. Res. 241, on agreeing to H. Res. 241, if ordered, and on the motion to suspend the rules and pass H.R. 406, which had been debated earlier and on which further proceedings had been postponed.
The House convened, returning from a recess continuing the legislative day of March 23.
The Speaker announced that the House do now recess for a period of less than 15 minutes.

At the conclusion of debate on H. Res. 241, the Chair put the question on ordering the previous question on the resolution and by voice vote, announced that the ayes had prevailed. Ms. Scanlon demanded the yeas and nays and the Chair postponed further proceedings on ordering the previous question until a time to be announced.
The House proceeded with one hour of debate on H. Res. 241.
Considered as privileged matter. H. Res. 241 — "Providing for consideration of the bill (H.R. 5) to ensure the rights of parents are honored and protected in the Nation's public schools."
The House proceeded with one minute speeches which by direction of the Chair, would be limited to 15 per side of the aisle.
The Chair designated Ms. Ross to lead the Members in reciting the Pledge of Allegiance to the Flag.
The Speaker announced approval of the Journal. Pursuant to clause 1, rule I, the Journal stands approved.
Today's prayer was offered by the House Chaplain, Chaplain Margaret Grun Kibben.
The House convened, returning from a recess continuing the legislative day of March 23.
The Speaker announced that the House do now recess. The next meeting is scheduled for 12:00 P.M. today.
The House proceeded with Morning-Hour Debate. At the conclusion of Morning-Hour, the House will recess until 12:00 p.m. for the start of legislative business.
The Speaker designated the Honorable Jerry L. Carl to act as Speaker pro tempore for today.
The House convened, starting a new legislative day.
